Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Situation2: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Story:
I sat on the edge of my bed, phone in hand, staring at two unread messages. My stepdad had texted, “Rough day. Can we talk?” He rarely reached out like this, and I knew he needed someone to listen, someone to ask if he was really okay. That’s what I’d promised myself I’d be for him—a step-child who cared, who checked in, who made sure he didn’t feel alone in this new family.

But just as I was about to call him, my girlfriend’s message popped up: “Can you come over? I really need you.” She’d had a terrible day at work, her boss’s harsh words still echoing in her head. I could picture her curled up on the couch, waiting for me to hold her, to tell her she was more than her job, that I was there for her no matter what.

My heart twisted. Both needed me, both expected me to be their support. I felt pulled in two directions, guilt and worry tangling inside me as I tried to decide who needed me more right now.
